articles.headline: Bankers Reaped Lavish Bonuses During Bailouts
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s million dollar club had nearly 5,000 members in 2008, New York’s attorney general reported.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s million dollar club had nearly 5,000 members in 2008, New York’s attorney general reported.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of top traders and bankers on Wall Street were awarded huge bonuses and pay packages last year, even as their employers were battered by the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: When Auto Plants Close, Only White Elephants Remain
articles.snippet: Communities are haunted by the huge empty buildings — which find few takers — that have been left behind by the automakers.
articles.abstract: Communities are haunted by the huge empty buildings — which find few takers — that have been left behind by the automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WIXOM, Mich.  The sheer size of the sites has inspired grand visions for redevelopment  a $1 billion football stadium, a huge Hollywood movie studio, even the world’s largest indoor tennis complex.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Living in Tents, and by the Rules, Under a Bridge
articles.snippet: A tent community for the homeless under a freeway overpass in downtown Providence, R.I., has written rules to live by.
articles.abstract: A tent community for the homeless under a freeway overpass in downtown Providence, R.I., has written rules to live by.

articles.headline: It May Be Outrageous, but Wall Street Pay Didn’t Cause This Crisis
articles.snippet: Even if a House bill to change Wall Street compensation is a move toward financial regulatory reform, there will have to be much larger steps taken to reach that goal.
articles.abstract: Even if a House bill to change Wall Street compensation is a move toward financial regulatory reform, there will have to be much larger steps taken to reach that goal.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a lot about Wall Street pay to make the rest of us livid, or at least jealous. And now Congress seems poised to act on it.

articles.headline: ‘Cash for Clunkers’ Car-Rebate Plan Sells Out in Days
articles.snippet: The program, which offered cash to people who traded in old cars for ones with higher fuel economy, was said to have exhausted its available funds, leaving its future in question.
articles.abstract: The program, which offered cash to people who traded in old cars for ones with higher fuel economy, was said to have exhausted its available funds, leaving its future in question.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  New-car shoppers appear to have already snapped up all the $1 billion that Congress appropriated for the “cash for clunkers” program, leading the Transportation Department to tell auto dealers Thursday night to stop offering the rebates.

articles.headline: Billions in Lehman Claims Could Bury an Elusive Insurer
articles.snippet: Capco could face nearly $11 billion in claims but has only about $150 million with which to meet them, according to industry estimates.
articles.abstract: Capco could face nearly $11 billion in claims but has only about $150 million with which to meet them, according to industry estimates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Next to a Chinese restaurant in Burlington, Vt., lurks a quiet guardian of Wall Street  an obscure insurance company that is supposed to protect big-money investors in the event of a catastrophic failure of a major brokerage firm.

articles.headline: Major Investor in Russia Sees Wide Fraud Scheme
articles.snippet: William Browder claims that some other Western investors colluded in a tax fraud and money-laundering scheme.
articles.abstract: William Browder claims that some other Western investors colluded in a tax fraud and money-laundering scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  William F. Browder, once the largest foreign investor in the Russian stock market, filed court documents in New York this week contending that other Western investors in Russia had colluded with the authorities to steal hundreds of millions of dollars through tax refunds and then laundered the money through New York banks.

articles.headline: After Rescue, New Weakness Seen at A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The weaknesses raise difficult questions for regulators, who normally step in when an insurer gets into trouble.
articles.abstract: The weaknesses raise difficult questions for regulators, who normally step in when an insurer gets into trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dozens of insurance companies that make up the American International Group show signs of considerable weakness even after their corporate parent got the biggest bailout in history, a review of state regulatory filings shows.

articles.headline: Ads Follow Web Users, and Get More Personal
articles.snippet: Marketers have started mining the mountain of offline information and connecting it to consumers’ browsers.
articles.abstract: Marketers have started mining the mountain of offline information and connecting it to consumers’ browsers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the concern and uproar over online privacy, marketers and data companies have always known much more about consumers’ offline lives, like income, credit score, home ownership, even what car they drive and whether they have a hunting license. Recently, some of these companies have started connecting this mountain of information to consumers’ browsers.

articles.headline: U.S. Economic Contraction Slowed in Quarter
articles.snippet: The economy shrank at a slower-than-expected annual rate of 1 percent from April through June.
articles.abstract: The economy shrank at a slower-than-expected annual rate of 1 percent from April through June.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy’s long decline leveled off significantly from April through June, the government reported on Friday, crystallizing expectations of a turnaround in the second half of the year.
articles.byline: By Catherine Rampell and Jack Healy

articles.headline: In Congress, a Jump-Start for Clunkers
articles.snippet: The House on Friday voted, 316 to 109, to provide emergency funds for the car-rebate program after the original funding was quickly snapped up.
articles.abstract: The House on Friday voted, 316 to 109, to provide emergency funds for the car-rebate program after the original funding was quickly snapped up.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As problems go in the nation’s capital these days, the White House could live with this one.
